results.title: Indians, Hit Hard by Climate Change, Closely Watch Paris Talks
results.abstract: Despite a range of environmental crises and health hazards, raising a vast population out of poverty remains a higher national priority in India than global warming.
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

results.title: In Beijing, a Day Off School for Smog Is No Fun for Anyone
results.abstract: Millions of families grappled with the unexpected closing of schools across China’s capital, which left parents searching for day care options and students facing additional homework.

results.title: Thousands of Migrants Stranded in Greece as Route North Is Narrowed
results.abstract: For the past several weeks only Syrians, Iraqis and Afghans have been allowed into Macedonia, leaving them in a country struggling to manage.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

results.title: German Woman Denies Role in Murders in Neo-Nazi Case
results.abstract: Beate Zschäpe, in a statement to a Munich court, rejected charges she had been part of an underground cell that killed nine immigrants and a policewoman from 2000 to 2007.

results.title: Thomas Piketty to India’s Elite: ‘Learn From History’
results.abstract: On a visit to Mumbai, the economist and author hopes India’s elite can “learn from the stupid mistakes of the other elites.”

results.title: British Petition to Keep Donald Trump Out of Country
results.abstract: Angered by the candidate’s comments about Muslims, more than 100,000 people have signed the petition to bar him from Britain on hate-speech grounds.

results.title: Afghanistan Hopes W.T.O. Membership Can Reboot Its Battered Economy
results.abstract: Optimists view the trade body’s seal of approval as a potential lift for the war-ravaged country whose chief export is opium and main “import” is international aid.

multimedia.caption: Afghan farmers harvesting opium sap in a poppy field near Jalalabad. Afghanistan “remains a poor, fragile state far from self-reliance,” an International Monetary Fund report said.

results.abstract: The police said that the ambassador, Glyn T. Davies, had diplomatic immunity, but that they were obliged by law to investigate the complaint.

results.title: Myanmar Political Shift Revives Debate on Sanctions

results.title: Americans Attracted to ISIS Find an ‘Echo Chamber’ on Social Media
results.abstract: As the White House takes on the challenge of the Islamic State, it is focusing on the online community of sympathizers in the United States, who number in the hundreds and fit no single profile.
results.byline: By SCOTT SHANE, MATT APUZZO and ERIC SCHMITT
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A collection of posts from Twitter accounts sympathetic to the Islamic State. Lions, a reference to warriors as “lions of Allah,” are a popular symbol. Some users praise the recent killings in San Bernardino, Calif., while others offer advice to prevent hacker groups like Anonymous from disabling pro-Islamic State accounts.

results.title: Tibor Rubin Is Dead at 86; Medal of Honor Was Delayed by Anti-Semitism
results.abstract: Corporal Rubin was a Hungarian-born American hero, who joined the United States Army to thank the nation and the troops that rescued him from a Nazi concentration camp.

multimedia.caption: Tibor Rubin, pictured in 1953, spent 30 months as a prisoner of war in North Korea. Fellow prisoners later testified about his willingness to sacrifice for the good of others.

results.title: Chinese Glacier’s Retreat Signals Trouble for Asian Water Supply
results.abstract: The Mengke Glacier in northwest China is receding fast, and towns along an arid corridor have suffered floods and landslides caused by sudden rainstorms.
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: The Mengke Glacier, one of China’s largest, retreated an average of 54 feet a year from 2005 to 2014. From 1993 to 2005, it retreated 26 feet a year.

results.title: Anxiety Grows in Texas With Syrians Due to Arrive Soon
results.abstract: The expected arrival of 21 of the refugees in the state this week has intensified concerns and fears about accepting Syrians in the wake of the Paris attacks last month.
